column1: Trujillo Alto (Spanish pronunciation: [tɾuˈxiʝo ˈalto]) is a municipality of Puerto Rico located in the Northern Coastal Plain and in the karst zone
column2: north of Caguas
column3: and Gurabo; southeast of San Juan
column4: and west of Carolina. Trujillo Alto is part of the San Juan Metropolitan Area
column5: which includes the municipalities of Bayamón
column8: and Toa Baja. The city is spread over 6 barrios and Trujillo Alto barrio-pueblo (the downtown area and the administrative center of the city). It is part of the San Juan-Caguas-Guaynabo Metropolitan Statistical Area.

column1: Trujillo Alto was officially founded in 1801
column2: but gained more importance during the 20th century. Due to its proximity to the capital
column3: San Juan
column4: the city has become a suburb of the metropolitan area
column5: which has sparked its growth during recent years. The population of Trujillo Alto has increased through the last century from 9
column8: it is Puerto Rico's tenth-most populated municipality.In 1953–54
column9: the Carraízo hydroelectric dam was constructed in Trujillo Alto by the Sumner Sollitt Construction Company of Chicago
column10: under contract by the Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority. The dam forms the Loíza Lake
column11: a reservoir which serves as the main source of the water supply for San Juan

column1: The region of what is now Trujillo Alto belonged to the Taíno region of Cayniabón
column2: which stretched from the northeast coast of Puerto Rico into the central region of the island. The region was led by cacique Canobaná. Archeological findings have identified two sites within the municipality of Trujillo Alto with archeological significance: Las Cuevas
column3: which was studied by Irving Rouse
column4: and Quebrada Grande.After the Spanish colonization
column5: families started settling at both sides of the Río Grande de Loíza. During the 17th Century
column6: the Spanish crown granted Alonso Pizarro Hermona
column8: a vast ranch that covered the region. Residents began using his family name to refer to the location. Eventually
column9: the inhabitants went to the Governor and asked for permit to build a chapel
column10: which was a requisite to officially found a town. Despite some opposition
column11: Trujillo Alto was founded on January 8
column12: 1801 under the name of Santa Cruz de Trujillo. Around 1820
column13: the name "Trujillo Alto" was more used to differentiate the town from that of Trujillo Bajo (which later became known as Carolina).

column2: communication to and from the town improved with the construction of two bridges: one into Río Piedras
column3: and the other into Río Grande. In 1844
column4: Trujillo Alto was composed of only five barrios. A few years later
column5: the first school was built. During that time
column6: population decreased notably due to an epidemic of cholera.

column1: The United States took control of Puerto Rico from Spain in the aftermath of the Spanish-American War under the terms of the Treaty of Paris of 1898. In 1899
column2: the United States conducted its first census of Puerto Rico
column3: finding that the population of Trujillo Alto was 5
column5: the Legislative Assembly of Puerto Rico approved a law for the consolidation of certain municipalities. As a result
column6: Trujillo Alto was incorporated into the town of Carolina. However
column7: in 1905 a new law revoked the previous one
column8: turning Trujillo Alto into an independent municipality again.The proximity of the city to the capital
column10: has sparked significant growth and development in the region. During the 20th century
column11: the population of Trujillo Alto increased dramatically. As of 2010
column12: the city is the tenth-most populous city of Puerto Rico. Mayor José Luis Cruz Cruz
column14: has labeled the city as "The New Metropolis".

column2: 2017 triggered numerous landslides in Trujillo Alto with the significant amount of rainfall.

column1: Trujillo Alto sits on the Northern Coastal Plain region of Puerto Rico. It is bordered by the municipalities of San Juan
column2: Carolina
column3: Gurabo
column4: and Caguas. Trujillo Alto is a small municipality
column5: covering only 21.47 square miles (55.6 km2).Trujillo Alto's terrain is mostly plain in the north
column6: while the south features small hills. Heights can range from 660–1

column1: Trujillo Alto's hydrographic system consists mainly of the Río Grande de Loíza (river)
column2: which crosses the municipality. There are also several creeks in the city: Colorada
column3: Infierno
column4: Limones
column10: Trujillo Alto is the site of Puerto Rico's main water reservoir: The Carraízo Dam
column11: at the Loíza Lake. Both were built in 1953 by the Puerto Rico Aqueducts and Sewers Authority (PRASA). Although it was originally built to generate hydroelectricity
column12: it is now used solely as a public water-supply source. The Loíza Lake is also used for sports and recreational fishing.

column1: Like all municipalities of Puerto Rico
column2: Trujillo Alto is subdivided into barrios. The municipal buildings
column3: central square and large Catholic church are located in a barrio referred to as "el pueblo".

column1: Trujillo Alto barrio-puebloTrujillo Alto's townscape is fairly simple. Most of the barrios are spread through the rural section of the city
column2: while the downtown area (Trujillo Alto Pueblo) is small
column3: consisting only of eight primary streets. This gave the city the nickname of the "City of the Eight Streets". Also
column4: there are no high-rise buildings and structures.

column1: Barrios (which are like minor civil divisions) and subbarrios
column2: in turn
column3: are further subdivided into smaller local populated place areas/units called sectores (sectors in English). The types of sectores may vary
column4: from normally sector to urbanización to reparto to barriada to residencial

column1: Of the 742 places on the list of Comunidades Especiales de Puerto Rico
column2: the following barrios
column3: communities
column4: sectors
column5: or neighborhoods were in Trujillo Alto: San Nicolás neighborhood

column1: There are several places of interest for tourists to visit in Trujillo Alto. The Bicentenary Walkway
column2: located in the entrance to the city at the PR-181
column3: features the remodeled historic steel bridge as well as a gazebo. It was built in 2001 to commemorate the 200 years of the foundation of Trujillo Alto.

column2: is the Luis Muñoz Marín Foundation which was established in 1980. It includes a museum
column3: a historic archive
column4: and a park.The Carraízo Dam and the Loíza Lake are also frequently visited. Other places of interest are the Convent Carmelitas de San José

column1: The economy of Trujillo Alto has relied mostly on agriculture
column2: particularly sugarcane
column3: coffee
column4: tobacco
column5: and minor fruits. Cattle ranching is also a source of economy in Trujillo Alto. In recent years
column6: commerce and industry have become integral parts of the economy of the city. Trujillo Alto is the site of several factories of nutritional products
column10: and others. There are also stone quarries in town for the production of building materials.

column2: Trujillo Alto's unemployment was 10.2%
column3: making it the second municipality with the lowest rate after Guaynabo.

column1: Trujillo Alto celebrates its patron saint festival in September. The Fiestas Patronales de Santa Cruz is a religious and cultural celebration that generally features parades
column2: games
column3: artisans
column4: amusement rides
column6: and live entertainment.The fifth annual Festival Trujillano de Orquideas (Orchid Festival) was held in July 2016. It is a festival where orchids are exhibited and sold.The Festival del Macabeo (Macabeo Festival)
column7: a festival celebrating a food specific to Trujillo Alto
column8: is celebrated each year around the second week of December.Other festivals and fairs celebrated in Trujillo Alto include an agricultural fair held in January and a Paso Fino Festival held in November.

column2: Trujillo Alto commemorated its bicentenary with the opening of a new park in the PR-181
column3: which included a remodeling of the historical steel bridge.

column1: There are a number of churches and chapels from several denominations in Trujillo Alto. The main parish
column2: Parroquia Santa Cruz
column3: was built in 1817. Part of a related structure was damaged by Hurricane San Felipe in 1928. The current structure was designed by Luis Perocier and built in 1933.Trujillo Alto has also been a place of pilgrimage for Catholics after a shrine to Our Lady of Lourdes was blessed in 1925. The site also features a grotto dedicated to Our Lady of Lourdes. The Lourdes grotto is visited frequently by religious people and tourists. There's also a convent in Trujillo Alto called the Convento Carmelitas de San José.

column1: Trujillo Alto doesn't have a professional sports team. However
column2: there are several sports facilities in the city for amateur and novice leagues. In 2011
column3: the Rubén Sánchez Montañez Court in Trujillo Alto
column4: hosted the Cangrejeros de Santurce team of the Baloncesto Superior Nacional (BSN)
column5: which is the professional basketball league. The facility has a capacity for 2
column7: Trujillo Alto celebrates the Arrecosta'o Marathon
column8: which is one of the most important events in the city. The race has been celebrated yearly since 1985. It originally covered a 6.2 mile (10 kilometer) trajectory around town
column10: it was shortened to 3.1 miles (5 kilometers). In 2010
column11: the marathon was recognized as one of the best organized events of the year.The Loíza Lake is also a frequent spot for sports and recreational fishing. The lake features a wide variety of fishes like: largemouth bass

column1: The macabeo is the most known typical food of Trujillo Alto. It is a fried dish made with green bananas and meat. The popularity of the dish is such that a festival is celebrated annually on its honor. The Macabeo Festival began in the early 80s
column2: and is held each year in December.

column1: The population of Trujillo Alto increased steadily during the 20th Century. Since 1920
column2: the population has risen roughly more than 300%. According to the 2010 census
column3: the municipality currently has 74
column4: 842 inhabitants. The decade from 2000 to 2010 is the only one that has shown a decrease in population during the last 110 years. Still
column5: Trujillo Alto's current population makes it the tenth municipality in Puerto Rico in terms of population.

column2: 72% of the population identifies themselves as White
column3: and 14.6% as African-American. Also
column4: 47.5% of the population identified themselves as males
column6: 25% of the population is under 18 years old. The next biggest percentage of population (20.7%) is between 35 and 49 years old.

column1: Like all municipalities in Puerto Rico
column2: Trujillo Alto is administered by a mayor. The first official mayor of Trujillo Alto was Juan Francisco Carazo
column3: who was one of the residents that vouched for the foundation of the town back in 1801. The current mayor is José Luis Cruz Cruz (from the Popular Democratic Party)
column4: who was elected at the 2004 general election.

column1: The city belongs to the Puerto Rico Senatorial district VIII
column2: which is represented by two Senators. In 2012
column3: Pedro A. Rodríguez and Luis Daniel Rivera were elected as District Senators. Representatives Javier Aponte Dalmau (District 38) and Roberto Rivera Ruiz (District 39)
column4: both from the PPD
column5: represent different regions of Trujillo Alto in the House of Representatives.

column1: The flag of Trujillo Alto features a white background with the town's coat of arms in the center.The coat of arms features a shield with a blue border
column2: with eight spurts of water representing the many springs
column3: creeks
column4: and rivers that flow in town. Inside the shield
column5: there's a silver field with three green mountains and a blue Latin cross above them. The flag features a white banner below the shield with the name of the city
column6: and a coronet in the form of a five-tower mural crown alluding to the Spanish crown. The banner and the coronet aren't featured in the flag.

column1: Trujillo Alto is known by various names. It is known as the "City of Springs" for its many rivers and creeks. It is also known as the "Town of the Eight Streets" because the downtown area consists of eight streets. Trujillo Alto is also known as the "City in the Country"
column2: for its proximity to the San Juan Metropolitan Area despite being mostly a mountain town. Finally
column3: it is also called the "Laid-back Town".

column1: The main road to Trujillo Alto is the PR-181 that crosses the municipality from north to south. Distance from the capital is roughly 15 minutes. Other highways that lead to Trujillo Alto are the #852 of the Quebrada Grande neighborhood and Dos Bocas
column2: the #175 of the neighborhood Carraízo
column3: the Las Cumbres Avenue and the #851 from La Gloria neighborhood.

column2: communication with the town was limited because of its location on the other side of the Río Grande de Loíza. The construction of two bridges in 1826 helped facilitate the trip to the town. In 1939
column3: the United States Army built a steel bridge in the entrance to the town on the PR-181
column4: to replace one of the older ones. Although the bridge is no longer used for vehicles
column5: it has become a symbol of the city and still stands today.The northern part of Trujillo Alto is serviced by the Puerto Rico Metropolitan Bus Authority with various stops along the PR-181 and nearby neighborhoods. Other public transportation in the city is provided by taxis

column1: There are 11 bridges in Trujillo Alto.
